report_title: Art and Office Supply Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Art and office supply manufacturers have contended with stark challenges. The growing number of businesses moving operations online has negatively impacted office supply sales. During the initial stages of the pandemic, many downstream businesses were required to pause operations, negatively impacting demand for art and office supplies. During this time, many companies moved toward online, paperless communication, a trend that spilled over into the following years. Although the economic recovery enabled demand to grow, these gains could not mitigate the pandemic-related losses. These trends have resulted in revenue dropping at an estimated CAGR of 3.4% to $3.3 billion through 2024, including a 0.6% gain that year alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand is Weakening in the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A major cause of the overall drop in demand for art and office supplies has been technology substitution since more people are substituting traditional art and office supplies with electronics and tools that are available online.

The majority of imports are low-cost goods from China, Mexico and Japan. Since manufacturers based in these countries frequently undercut domestic producers because of cheaper labor costs, imports now satisfy more than 40.0% of domestic demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Companies Are Shifting to Save Profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Major buyers generate a large share of revenue, giving them significant bargaining power. This has enabled them to negotiate prices and request advantageous terms and conditions when entering contractual relationships with manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Led to Drastic Revenue Losses
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Prominent price competition has caused smaller enterprises to leave the industry or consolidate, although some players have been able to restructure their operations and reduce costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changes in Consumer Preferences Negatively Impact Producers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Manufacturers will continue to struggle to compete with consumers favoring imported products and the widespread adoption of paperless solutions, such as reviewing documents on computers and tablets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumers will continue to move away from traditional writing and drawing tools toward electronic alternatives, harming demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although students will likely continue to purchase office supplies, they are also expected to move toward electronic alternatives.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Profitability is Probably Going to be Minimal
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Manufacturers' profit will likely be constrained by significant import penetration and weakening domestic demand. Although manufacturers are likely to continue adopting automated solutions, a lower need for art and office supplies will prevent profit growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: There Are Still Future Growth Opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To compete with more affordable imports, domestic producers will likely move away from lower-profit products by focusing on producing higher-quality, innovative products, US manufacturers aim to boost sales despite the industry's general decline.

industry_definition: Operators in the Art and Office Supply Manufacturing industry purchase ink, wood, plastics and other materials to manufacture a range of art and office supplies. Industry products include pens, pencils, art goods, staplers, marking devices and carbon paper. Customers include businesses, consumers, wholesalers and office supply retailers.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Aggregate private investment
threats: Low Outlier Growth: Demand from office supply stores

key_trends: Businesses are increasingly conducting business online, lowering their need for office supplies. As work-from-home policies made the employment of digital substitutes necessary, demand for supplies weakened.
Significant import penetration and overall weaker demand harm demand. Foreign producers can charge lower prices, appealing to an increasingly price-conscious population.

Improving economic conditions are unlikely to boost sales. Office and art supply revenue growth will likely remain muted as consumers and businesses continue to adopt technology that acts as a substitute.

Manufacturers are subject to a variety of federal, state and local laws. These laws aim to ensure that producers adhere to standards and practices that promote environmental protection and workers and product safety.

Manufacturers are supported by government organizations and programs that help them succeed. One of the most common types of support comes in the form of tax concessions designed to reduce the financial burden on companies and encourage growth.

Writing instruments make up the majority of the goods manufactured. The widespread usage of computers, printers and photocopiers has harmed demand for writing instruments among businesses and consumers.

Only a small percentage of the supplies manufacturers produce are intermediate goods used in other manufacturing sectors. Office supplies are typically marketed to wholesalers, retailers or big corporations directly for domestic and global distribution.

The western region of the United States has a significant connection to art and office supply manufacturers. California, in particular, is home to many companies in this industry, including some of the largest and most well-known brands.

The location of industrial facilities is heavily influenced by the accessibility of raw resources. To save money on transportation and guarantee a steady supply, businesses may consider locating their activities close to the source of the raw materials.

Outside factors like technological alternatives and imported goods result in significant competition. Although larger producers control a significant portion of the market, there is still room for specialist businesses to thrive in this industry.
Large manufacturers largely compete among themselves. However, the widespread acceptance of substitutes makes internal competition less of a threat to domestic producers.

Significant import competition and the substituting of electronic devices for conventional communication methods and art and office supplies have harmed demand. As a result, many companies in the industry were compelled to reduce their workforces or even close down completely.

To adapt to modern changes, supply manufacturers may need to focus on developing new products. This helps cater to the changing needs and preferences of consumers, such as digital art tools and software.
Manufacturers have been adopting automated solutions, lowering wages. The implementation of machinery and low levels of new product development have enabled wages to fall as a share of revenue.
Falling demand has been harming profit. The combination of weaker demand, price-based competition and volatile operating costs has made producers less profitable.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers account for the largest portion of sales as they both use office supplies for their daily operations and as a product offering for customers. Retailers have been purchasing products directly from manufacturers to lower purchase costs. This trend is more common among large manufacturers with significant purchasing power. Concentration in this downstream market has aided clients like Walmart in leveraging their bargaining power and demanding lower prices, placing downward pressure on manufacturers' profitability. Retailers adapting to changes in consumer behavior, mainly the preference toward online shopping, has enabled them to solidify their position as the largest buyers of art and office goods.

Wholesalers are an essential intermediary in the distribution of goods, acting as a conduit between producers and consumers. Wholesalers purchase products from manufacturers to distribute across various downstream markets, including individuals, retailers and other businesses that use office supplies for daily operations. Bypassing wholesalers is becoming popular among retailers as purchasing directly from manufacturers can be a cost-saving measure and offers more control over procurement. This trend has placed downward pressure on wholesalers' share of the market. Large businesses with a lot of purchasing power may also make direct purchases from manufacturers. These are businesses from different sectors that use a lot of office supplies.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Carbon paper, inked ribbons and other office supplies
products_and_services.product_description: Office supplies include products like tape dispensers, paper cutters and trimmers, pencil sharpeners, staplers and staples. This segment also includes carbon paper and ink ribbons.
Art supplies and goods include products like paint, canvas, brushes, chalk, watercolors, clay, palettes, lead pencils, and colored pencils, among many others.
The pens and mechanical pencils segment includes ballpoint pens, felt tip markers, fountain pens, pen refills, cartridges and all mechanical pencils.
Tools used to mark an item include: branding irons, date stamps, embossing stamps, hand-operated stamps, metal stamps, rubber stamps, stamp pads, other marking tools.

tier_1_suppliers: Wood Product Manufacturing in the US
Plastic Products Miscellaneous Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Office Supply Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Office Stationery Wholesaling in the US
Hobby & Toy Stores in the US
Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most art and office supplies are sold to end customers through the retail sector. Therefore, activity in the Office Supply Stores industry indicates changes in demand for craft and office supplies.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Falling Demand for Supplies Harms Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports of office, writing and drawing supplies saw a significant decline in 2020 at the peak of the pandemic, but started improving 2021 as economic activity re-emerged.

Demand for imported supplies has been impacted by declining demand for office and art supplies. This trend has been enhanced in recent years by the growing popularity of paperless operations and conducting business online.

international_trade_points.trade_title: LOWER PRODUCTION COSTS OVERSEAS ATTRACT MANUFACTURERS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Oftentimes, manufacturers can find operating conditions overseas to be more favorable. This has resulted in multiple manufacturers offshoring production capabilities to countries with lower operating costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE PANDEMIC'S IMPACT ON THE OFFICE SUPPLY INDUSTRY
international_trade_points.trade_description: The value of the US dollar has grown significantly in recent years as significant inflation, supply chain disruptions and multiple international conflicts, such as the pandemic, impacted trade activity.

international_trade_points.trade_title: CANADA AND MEXICO ARE THE MOST POPULAR DESTINATIONS
international_trade_points.trade_description: The main export destinations for the US office supply industry are Canada and Mexico. More than half of all art and office supplies exported from the United States are destined for these two countries.

business_locations.location_description: The West area of the United States is a popular location for manufacturers in the Art and Office Supply Manufacturing industry due to a combination of several factors. One of the primary reasons is the area's accessibility to important western ports like the Port of Los Angeles. The Port of Los Angeles is the largest port in the United States in terms of container volume and is a critical gateway for international trade with Asia and the Pacific Rim. The largest state in the West is California, which is also the location of several businesses that produce art and office supplies.

There has been a significant relocation of industrial jobs to the Southern states. This shift has been driven by a variety of factors, including lower labor costs, favorable business climates and more relaxed regulations. The Arts and Office Supply Manufacturing industry is an important sector within the broader manufacturing market and is characterized by a high degree of competition. The Southeast region of the United States is already home to many well-established Arts and Office Supply businesses that have built strong brand recognition and a loyal customer base over the years.

The United States' Mid-Atlantic and New England areas both contribute significantly to the Art & Office Supply Manufacturing industry. With a long history of manufacturing, these areas have honed their skills in a variety of fields, including paper and printing, bookbinding, and furniture production. New York has the most locations out of these two regions. Being close to retailers and wholesalers in the state of New York can be very advantageous to business owners in the industry because the state is well-liked by manufacturers due to its huge population and high amount of enterprises that demand large quantities of office supplies.

The United States' Mid-Atlantic and New England areas both contribute significantly to the Art & Office Supply Manufacturing industry. With a long history of manufacturing, these areas have honed their skills in a variety of fields, including paper and printing, bookbinding, and furniture production.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Clean Air Act requires compliance with air quality standards and empowers the Environmental Protection Agency to establish and enforce limits on the emission of pollutants. The act establishes regulations for sulfur and nitrogen oxides and strict requirements for ozone emissions and other toxic materials.

The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface water. The act establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, in addition to water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

Manufacturers have to ensure the safety of workers, mainly through noise and dust standards. Similarly, the act requires manufacturers to provide proper training on the use of machinery and procedures to reduce workplace risks.

factors_decreased_barrier: The manufacture of art and office supplies involves both human and automated procedures, which in general characterizes the industry as having a moderate level of labor intensity.

basis_points.basis_description: Outside factors like technological alternatives and imported goods result in significant competition.
Large manufacturers largely compete among themselves.
However, the widespread acceptance of substitutes makes internal competition less of a threat to domestic producers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: There are a few large, international corporations with sizable market shares in the writing instrument sector of the industry, and a sizable number of smaller, niche producers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major office supply merchants hold large share
concentration_points.concentration_description: There are a few major office supply merchants that hold a sizable market share in the office supplies sector, along with numerous smaller, specialty competitors.
Overall, variables like product differentiation, economies of scale, brand recognition, distribution channels, and consumer preferences affect the degree of market share concentration.

Currently, underperforming businesses have been forced to merge with bigger rivals or leave the market entirely. Strong competition and slowing demand have led to consolidations, mergers, and acquisitions and corporate departures.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SIGNIFICANT INPUT PRICE VOLATILITY HAS AFFECTED MANUFACTURERS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest portion of costs for the industry is made up of purchases, which also include materials for packaging, plastics, metal fabrication, wood, and other products. The price of plastic materials and resin has jumped since the start of the pandemic, mainly as a response to supply chain disruptions and a jump in demand for manufactured products.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The manufacture of art and office supplies involves both human and automated procedures
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The manufacture of art and office supplies involves both human and automated procedures, which in general characterizes the industry as having a moderate level of labor intensity.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The rate of new patent additions to the industry is low
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent additions to the industry is low. This is combined with a low concentration of innovation. Both factors being low suggests that new technology entry is slow and widespread, which limits the threat of disruptive threats hurting leading industry operators.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE RISE OF TECHNOLOGY THREATENS DEMAND
volatility_points.volatility_description: Technological developments have resulted in consumers and businesses seeking cost-saving alternatives that are also more convenient.
Consumer spending shifts, import competition, price swings in raw materials, currency exchange rate fluctuations and economic recessions are a few factors that might cause revenue to fluctuate.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The 2020 pandemic negatively impacted demand for office supplies
volatility_points.volatility_description: The 2020 pandemic negatively impacted demand for office supplies, as many businesses were required to pause or close operations. The falling demand from the commercial sector led to drastic revenue losses.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The recent appreciation of the US dollar has negatively impacted demand for domestic supplies
volatility_points.volatility_description: The recent appreciation of the US dollar has negatively impacted demand for domestic supplies, as imported products become comparatively more affordable. Significant price-based competition has negatively impacted domestic producers and harmed demand.

volatility_points.volatility_title: To lessen the impact of revenue volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: To lessen the impact of revenue volatility, businesses in the sector have improved their supply chain management, diversified their product portfolios, and entered new markets.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for art and office supplies is not a major factor in manufacturers' performance. The slow growth of the industry can be attributed more to competition from abroad than macroeconomic events. Manufacturers are increasingly opting to move operations overseas as a cost-saving measure, a trend that harms domestic production.

FAQs.question: Have export opportunities offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: While some US manufacturing industries offer value-added products that other countries cannot offer, companies across the world in this industry generally offer the same type of product. Domestic manufacturers benefit from the perceived higher quality of domestic art and office supplies, although this does little to persuade cost-conscious consumers.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: This industry is not rapidly changing and consumers are generally not demanding new types of products. Little product innovation results in lower research and development expenses than in industries undergoing rapid change.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: The industry's main buyers are wholesalers and retailers throughout the country. While there is not one central location that is ideal for the industry to be located in or near, companies should be located near their largest buyers in order to decrease transport costs.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: While automation may not fully replace humans anytime soon, companies should seek to invest in robots to save on labor expenses and create a more streamlined and efficient process.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: New technology, including blockchain, is used by companies to create a more streamlined production process. Everything from manufacturing to distribution to recalls may be more efficiently controlled using new technology.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Tariff makes imported products more expensive in an effort to encourage consumers to purchase domestically-produced products. Low operating costs overseas can enable foreign manufacturers to charge lower prices, sometimes offsetting the cost of tariffs.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly affected profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: There are few formal regulatory barriers that affect manufacturers' financial situation. Regulation is generally more granular, affecting manufacturing sectors as a whole instead of this industry in particular.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Unlike in other industries, products produced by industry companies have a long shelf life. As a result, if a company needs to hold on to a particular product longer than expected, there should not be any more of a challenge to sell it later.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Downstream buyers are generally wholesalers or retailers, not consumers. Manufacturers may offer payment plans as encouragement, especially for large orders and reputable companies.

FAQs.question: Ability to pass on cost increases
FAQs.answer: Rising input prices can cause a rise in the price of office supplies. A company that can pass these increases on to downstream wholesalers and retailers can maintain profit levels. However, this is becoming increasingly difficult as large retailers like Walmart take up greater portions of the downstream market, giving it more power in price negotiations.

FAQs.question: Access to niche markets
FAQs.answer: A degree of specialization within a company can provide access to niche markets, such as erasable markers. Serving niche markets enables manufacturers to develop patents and reduce revenue volatility over time as a loyal customer base is built up.

FAQs.question: Establishment of brand names
FAQs.answer: In a market where many products have similar functionality and prices are under pressure, the ability to differentiate via branding can help gain market share and relieve margin pressure.

FAQs.question: How much of your sales are from online channels? How does rising online activity affect demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: The internet, along with computers and printers, has reduced demand for art and office supplies as more business operations and creative processes are performed and stored on computers and through the internet. Retailers are shifting more towards online sales of these products, which is expected to continue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How do you take advantage when the trade-weighted index decreases?
FAQs.answer: Domestic manufacturers benefit from a weak US dollar, partly through an increase in demand for exports and partly through weaker import competition. Manufacturers must consider other factors, including trade conditions, when planning export strategy.

FAQs.question: How have current levels of demand from office supply stores affected your company? Are certain products more heavily affected when demand from office supply stores fluctuates?
FAQs.answer: The majority of art and office supplies that manufacturers produce are sold to end customers through the retail sector. Activity in office supply stores is important to manufacturers because it indicates changes in demand for art and office supplies.
